children.help:
The prefix/path that is used to call the toolchain. The default setting assumes
a crosstool-ng gcc setup that is in your PATH.
children.name: SDK_TOOLPREFIX
children.title: Compiler toolchain path/prefix

children.help:
The executable name/path that is used to run python. On some systems Python 2.x
may need to be invoked as python2.

(Note: This option is used with the legacy GNU Make build system only.)
children.name: SDK_PYTHON
children.title: Python 2 interpreter

children.help:
Adds --warn-undefined-variables to MAKEFLAGS. This causes make to
print a warning any time an undefined variable is referenced.

This option helps find places where a variable reference is misspelled
or otherwise missing, but it can be unwanted if you have Makefiles which
depend on undefined variables expanding to an empty string.

(Note: this option is used with the legacy GNU Make build system only.)
children.name: SDK_MAKE_WARN_UNDEFINED_VARIABLES
children.title: 'make' warns on undefined variables

children.help:
The serial port that's connected to the ESP chip. This can be overridden by setting the ESPPORT
environment variable.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_PORT
children.title: Default serial port

children.help:
Default baud rate to use while communicating with the ESP chip. Can be overridden by
setting the ESPBAUD variable.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_BAUD
children.title: Default baud rate

children.help:
The flasher tool can send data compressed using zlib, letting the ROM on the ESP chip
decompress it on the fly before flashing it. For most payloads, this should result in a
speed increase.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_COMPRESSED
children.title: Use compressed upload

children.help:
Mode the flash chip is flashed in, as well as the default mode for the
binary to run in.

The esptool.py flashes firmware at DIO mode when user select "QIO", "QOUT" or "DIO" mode.
children.name: FLASHMODE
children.title: Flash SPI mode

children.help: The SPI flash frequency to be used.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_FLASHFREQ
children.title: Flash SPI speed

children.help:
SPI flash size, in megabytes. Users must not configure a larger value than their real flash size.
Otherwise an unexpected result may cause if users read/write a wrong address of flash.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE
children.title: Flash size

children.help:
Configure whether esptool.py should reset the ESP32 before flashing.

Automatic resetting depends on the RTS & DTR signals being
wired from the serial port to the ESP32. Most USB development
boards do this internally.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_BEFORE
children.title: Before flashing

children.help:
Configure whether esptool.py should reset the ESP8266 after flashing.

Automatic resetting depends on the RTS & DTR signals being
wired from the serial port to the ESP32. Most USB development
boards do this internally.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_AFTER
children.title: After flashing

children.help:
Baud rate to use when running 'make monitor' to view serial output
from a running chip.

Can override by setting the MONITORBAUD environment variable.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_MONITOR_BAUD
children.title: 'make monitor' baud rate

children.help:
Enable this option, software will initialize SPI flash clock and I/O mode at bootloader instead of at APP.
So it will speed up system starting and reduce the time cost at loading firmware.

If your system bootloader is based on v3.0, the option must not be enable, because the v3.0 bootloader don't support
this function.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_INIT_SPI_FLASH
children.title: Bootloader init SPI flash

children.help: Specify how much output to see in bootloader logs.
children.name: LOG_BOOTLOADER_LEVEL
children.title: Bootloader log verbosity

children.help: If enable this option, bootloader will check the sum of app binary data before load it to run.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_CHECK_APP_SUM
children.title: Check APP binary data sum before loading

children.help: If enable this option, bootloader will check the hash of app binary data before load it to run.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_CHECK_APP_HASH
children.title: Check APP binary data hash before loading

children.help:
This value is ignored unless flash mode is set to QIO or QOUT *and* the SPI flash pins have been
overriden by setting the efuses SPI_PAD_CONFIG_xxx.

When this is the case, the Efuse config only defines 3 of the 4 Quad I/O data pins. The WP pin (aka ESP32
pin "SD_DATA_3" or SPI flash pin "IO2") is not specified in Efuse. That pin number is compiled into the bootloader
instead.

The default value (GPIO 7) is correct for WP pin on ESP32-D2WD integrated flash.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_SPI_WP_PIN
children.title: SPI Flash WP Pin when customising pins via efuse (read help)

children.help:
If this option is enabled, and VDDSDIO LDO is set to 1.8V (using EFUSE
or MTDI bootstrapping pin), bootloader will change LDO settings to
output 1.9V instead. This helps prevent flash chip from browning out
during flash programming operations.

This option has no effect if VDDSDIO is set to 3.3V, or if the internal
VDDSDIO regulator is disabled via efuse.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_VDDSDIO_BOOST
children.title: VDDSDIO LDO voltage

children.help:
The selected GPIO will be configured as an input with internal pull-up enabled.
To trigger a factory reset, this GPIO must be pulled low on reset.
Note that GPIO34-39 do not have an internal pullup and an external one must be provided.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_NUM_PIN_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: Number of the GPIO input for factory reset

children.help: The device will boot from "factory" partition (or OTA slot 0 if no factory partition is present) after a factory reset.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_OTA_DATA_ERASE
children.title: Clear OTA data on factory reset (select factory partition)

children.help:
Allows customers to select which data partitions will be erased while factory reset.

Specify the names of partitions as a comma-delimited with optional spaces for readability. (Like this: "nvs, phy_init, ...")
Make sure that the name specified in the partition table and here are the same.
Partitions of type "app" cannot be specified here.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_DATA_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: Comma-separated names of partitions to clear on factory reset

children.help:
Allows to reset the device to factory settings:
- clear one or more data partitions;
- boot from "factory" partition.
The factory reset will occur if there is a GPIO input pulled low while device starts up.
See settings below.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: GPIO triggers factory reset

children.help:
For the small SPI Flash solution, there maybe no enough space for the test app partition.
By enable this option, test app will locate in ota_1 partition by default.
After ota, the test app will be erased and re-write as new app.

If you disable this, make sure there has a test app partition in you partition table CVS.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_APP_TEST_IN_OTA_1
children.title: Put test app in the ota_1 partition

children.help:
The selected GPIO will be configured as an input with internal pull-up enabled.
To trigger a test app(the second ota firmware), this GPIO must be pulled low on reset.
After the GPIO input is deactivated and the device reboots, the old application will boot.
(factory or OTA[x]).
children.name: BOOTLOADER_NUM_PIN_APP_TEST
children.title: Number of the GPIO input to boot TEST partition

children.help:
Allows to run the test app from "TEST" partition.
A boot from "test" partition will occur if there is a GPIO input pulled low while device starts up.
See settings below.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_APP_TEST
children.title: GPIO triggers boot from test app partition

children.help:
The GPIO must be held low continuously for this period of time after reset
before a factory reset or test partition boot (as applicable) is performed.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_HOLD_TIME_GPIO
children.title: Hold time of GPIO for reset/test mode (seconds)

children.help:
On first boot, the bootloader will generate a key which is not readable externally or by software. A digest is generated from the bootloader image itself. This digest will be verified on each subsequent boot.

Enabling this option means that the bootloader cannot be changed after the first time it is booted.
children.name: SECURE_BOOTLOADER_ONE_TIME_FLASH
children.title: One-time flash

children.help:
Generate a reusable secure bootloader key, derived (via SHA-256) from the secure boot signing key.

This allows the secure bootloader to be re-flashed by anyone with access to the secure boot signing key.

This option is less secure than one-time flash, because a leak of the digest key from one device allows reflashing of any device that uses it.
children.name: SECURE_BOOTLOADER_REFLASHABLE
children.title: Reflashable

children.help:
Path to the key file used to sign partition tables and app images for secure boot. Once secure boot is enabled, bootloader will only boot if partition table and app image are signed.

Key file is an ECDSA private key (NIST256p curve) in PEM format.

Path is evaluated relative to the project directory.

You can generate a new signing key by running the following command:
espsecure.py generate_signing_key secure_boot_signing_key.pem

See docs/security/secure-boot.rst for details.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_SIGNING_KEY
children.title: Secure boot private signing key

children.help:
Once secure boot is enabled, bootloader will only boot if partition table and app image are signed.

If enabled, these binary files are signed as part of the build process. The file named in "Secure boot private signing key" will be used to sign the image.

If disabled, unsigned app/partition data will be built. They must be signed manually using espsecure.py (for example, on a remote signing server.)
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_BUILD_SIGNED_BINARIES
children.title: Sign binaries during build

children.help:
Path to a public key file used to verify signed images. This key is compiled into the bootloader,
and may also be used to verify signatures on OTA images after download.

Key file is in raw binary format, and can be extracted from a
PEM formatted private key using the espsecure.py
extract_public_key command.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_VERIFICATION_KEY
children.title: Secure boot public signature verification key

children.help:
You can disable some of the default protections offered by secure boot, in order to enable testing or a custom combination of security features.

Only enable these options if you are very sure.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_INSECURE
children.title: Allow potentially insecure options

children.help:
Build a bootloader which enables secure boot on first boot.

Once enabled, secure boot will not boot a modified bootloader. The bootloader will only load a partition table or boot an app if the data has a verified digital signature. There are implications for reflashing updated apps once secure boot is enabled.

When enabling secure boot, JTAG and ROM BASIC Interpreter are permanently disabled by default.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ENABLED
children.title: Enable secure boot in bootloader (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
You can disable some of the default protections offered by flash encryption, in order to enable testing or a custom combination of security features.

Only enable these options if you are very sure.

Refer to docs/security/secure-boot.rst and docs/security/flash-encryption.rst for details.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_INSECURE
children.title: Allow potentially insecure options

children.help:
If this option is set, flash contents will be encrypted by the bootloader on first boot.

Note: After first boot, the system will be permanently encrypted. Re-flashing an encrypted
system is complicated and not always possible.

Read https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/flash-encryption.html before enabling.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED
children.title: Enable flash encryption on boot (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
By default, the BASIC ROM Console starts on reset if no valid bootloader is
read from the flash.

When either flash encryption or secure boot are enabled, the default is to
disable this BASIC fallback mode permanently via efuse.

If this option is set, this efuse is not burned and the BASIC ROM Console may
remain accessible.  Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ALLOW_ROM_BASIC
children.title: Leave ROM BASIC Interpreter available on reset

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable JTAG (across entire chip) on first boot when either secure boot or flash encryption is enabled.

Setting this option leaves JTAG on for debugging, which negates all protections of flash encryption and some of the protections of secure boot.

Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ALLOW_JTAG
children.title: Allow JTAG Debugging

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader encryption access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access hardware encryption.

It is recommended to only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_ENCRYPT
children.title: Leave UART bootloader encryption enabled

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader decryption access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access hardware decryption.

Only set this option in testing environments. Setting this option allows complete bypass of flash encryption.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_DECRYPT
children.title: Leave UART bootloader decryption enabled

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader flash cache access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access the flash cache.

Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_CACHE
children.title: Leave UART bootloader flash cache enabled

children.help:
If this option is set, all permanent secure boot changes (via Efuse) are disabled.

Log output will state changes which would be applied, but they will not be.

This option is for testing purposes only - it completely disables secure boot protection.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_TEST_MODE
children.title: Secure boot test mode: don't permanently set any efuses

children.help:
The partition table to flash to the ESP32. The partition table
determines where apps, data and other resources are expected to
be found.

The predefined partition table CSV descriptions can be found
in the components/partition_table directory. Otherwise it's
possible to create a new custom partition CSV for your application.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_TYPE
children.title: Partition Table

children.help:
Name of the custom partition CSV filename. This path is evaluated
relative to the project root directory.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_CUSTOM_FILENAME
children.title: Custom partition CSV file

children.help: The partition table cannot be placed at application address.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_OFFSET
children.title: Partition table offset address at flash

children.help:
This option sets compiler optimization level (gcc -O argument).

- for "Release" setting, -Os flag is added to CFLAGS.
- for "Debug" setting, -Og flag is added to CFLAGS.

"Release" with -Os produces smaller & faster compiled code but it
may be harder to correlated code addresses to source files when debugging.

To add custom optimization settings, set CFLAGS and/or CPPFLAGS
in project makefile, before including $(IDF_PATH)/make/project.mk. Note that
custom optimization levels may be unsupported.
children.name: COMPILER_OPTIMIZATION
children.title: Optimization Level

children.help: Enable assertions. Assertion content and line number will be printed on failure.
children.name: COMPILER_OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_ENABLE
children.title: Enabled

children.help:
Enable silent assertions. Failed assertions will abort(), user needs to
use the aborting address to find the line number with the failed assertion.
children.name: COMPILER_OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_SILENT
children.title: Silent (saves code size)

children.help: If assertions are disabled, -DNDEBUG is added to CPPFLAGS.
children.name: COMPILER_OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_DISABLE
children.title: Disabled (sets -DNDEBUG)

children.help:
Assertions can be:

- Enabled. Failure will print verbose assertion details. This is the default.

- Set to "silent" to save code size (failed assertions will abort() but user
  needs to use the aborting address to find the line number with the failed assertion.)

- Disabled entirely (not recommended for most configurations.) -DNDEBUG is added
  to CPPFLAGS in this case.
children.name: COMPILER_OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTION_LEVEL
children.title: Assertion level

children.help:
Enabling this option compiles all IDF C++ files with exception support enabled.

Disabling this option disables C++ exception support in all compiled files, and any libstdc++ code
which throws an exception will abort instead.

Enabling this option currently adds an additional ~500 bytes of heap overhead
when an exception is thrown in user code for the first time.
children.name: COMPILER_CXX_EXCEPTIONS
children.title: Enable C++ exceptions

children.help:
Stack smashing protection mode. Emit extra code to check for buffer overflows, such as stack
smashing attacks. This is done by adding a guard variable to functions with vulnerable objects.
The guards are initialized when a function is entered and then checked when the function exits.
If a guard check fails, program is halted. Protection has the following modes:

- In NORMAL mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector) only functions that call alloca, and functions with
  buffers larger than 8 bytes are protected.

- STRONG mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector-strong) is like NORMAL, but includes additional functions
  to be protected -- those that have local array definitions, or have references to local frame
  addresses.

- In OVERALL mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector-all) all functions are protected.

Modes have the following impact on code performance and coverage:

- performance: NORMAL > STRONG > OVERALL

- coverage: NORMAL < STRONG < OVERALL
children.name: COMPILER_STACK_CHECK_MODE
children.title: Stack smashing protection mode

children.help: Stack smashing protection.
children.name: COMPILER_STACK_CHECK

children.help:
Adds -Wwrite-strings flag for the C/C++ compilers.

For C, this gives string constants the type ``const char[]`` so that
copying the address of one into a non-const ``char *`` pointer
produces a warning. This warning helps to find at compile time code
that tries to write into a string constant.

For C++, this warns about the deprecated conversion from string
literals to ``char *``.
children.name: COMPILER_WARN_WRITE_STRINGS
children.title: Enable -Wwrite-strings warning flag

children.help:
Specify how much output to see in logs by default.
You can set lower verbosity level at runtime using
esp_log_level_set function.

Note that this setting limits which log statements
are compiled into the program. So setting this to, say,
"Warning" would mean that changing log level to "Debug"
at runtime will not be possible.
children.name: LOG_DEFAULT_LEVEL
children.title: Default log verbosity

children.help:
Enable ANSI terminal color codes in bootloader output.

In order to view these, your terminal program must support ANSI color codes.
children.name: LOG_COLORS
children.title: Use ANSI terminal colors in log output

children.help: Enable this option, user can set tag level.
children.name: LOG_SET_LEVEL
children.title: Enable log set level

children.help:
Enable this option, also enable "TCP_QUEUE_OOSEQ", "TCP_HIGH_SPEED_RETRANSMISSION" and
"SOC_FULL_ICACHE", so lwip should cache TCP message received in disorder sequence and
chip should full 32 KB IRAM as icache. For these 2 reasons, the global heap user can used
may reduce a lot.
children.name: LWIP_HIGH_THROUGHPUT
children.title: Enable lwip high throughput

children.help: Link LWIP global data(.bss .data COMMON) from DRAM to IRAM.
children.name: LWIP_GLOBAL_DATA_LINK_IRAM
children.title: Link LWIP global data to IRAM

children.help:
Set TCPIP task receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The value should be bigger than UDP/TCP mail box size.
children.name: TCPIP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: TCPIP task receive mail box size

children.name: LWIP_ARP_TABLE_SIZE
children.title: Number of active MAC-IP address pairs cached

children.name: LWIP_ARP_MAXAGE
children.title: The time an ARP entry stays valid after its last update

children.help: Enable the option can enable LWIP socket IPv6 multicast configuration.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_MLD_SOCK
children.title: LWIP socket supports IPv6 multicast configuration

children.help:
Enable the option can enable LWIP socket multithread and all
function will be thread safe.
children.name: LWIP_SOCKET_MULTITHREAD
children.title: LWIP socket supports multithread

children.help: Enable this option, send speed of nonblock TCP will increase obviously.
children.name: ENABLE_NONBLOCK_SPEEDUP
children.title: Speed up send speed of nonblock TCP

children.help:
The function is only used by socket multi-thread.

Enable this option can set the target socket to enable the "SO_LINGER" and config timeout to be "0" when it is created.
It means that if close the socket, all send queue will be dropped, so heap memory can be collected immediately,
but some packets which are waiting to be sent will lost.
children.name: SET_SOLINGER_DEFAULT
children.title: set socket SO_LINGER default

children.help:
When UDP sync send count reaches the value, then the packet should
be lost and LWIP core thread wake up the up-level send thread.
children.name: ESP_UDP_SYNC_RETRY_MAX
children.title: LWIP socket UDP sync send retry max count

children.help:
Enable the option can enable LWIP socket UDP sync send. CPU cost
should decrease but memory cost increase and it can make UDP
throughput increase a lot.
children.name: ESP_UDP_SYNC_SEND
children.title: LWIP socket UDP sync send

children.help:
Sockets take up a certain amount of memory, and allowing fewer
sockets to be open at the same time conserves memory. Specify
the maximum amount of sockets here. The valid value is from 1
to 16.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_SOCKETS
children.title: Max number of open sockets

children.help:
Enabling this option means that any incoming broadcast or multicast
packet will be copied to all of the local sockets that it matches
(may be more than one if SO_REUSEADDR is set on the socket.)

This increases memory overhead as the packets need to be copied,
however they are only copied per matching socket. You can safely
disable it if you don't plan to receive broadcast or multicast
traffic on more than one socket at a time.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE_RXTOALL
children.title: SO_REUSEADDR copies broadcast/multicast to all matches

children.help:
Enabling this option allows binding to a port which remains in
TIME_WAIT.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE
children.title: Enable SO_REUSEADDR option

children.help: Enabling this option allows checking for available data on a netconn.
children.name: LWIP_SO_RCVBUF
children.title: Enable SO_RCVBUF option

children.name: LWIP_TCP_CLOSE_TIMEOUT_MS_DEFAULT
children.title: TCP socket/netconn close waits time to send the FIN

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP packets

children.name: LWIP_IP_REASS_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: Total maximum amount of pbufs waiting to be reassembled

children.name: LWIP_IP_SOF_BROADCAST
children.title: Enable broadcast filter per pcb on udp and raw send operation

children.name: LWIP_IP_SOF_BROADCAST_RECV
children.title: Enable the broadcast filter on recv operations

children.name: LWIP_RAW
children.title: Enable application layer to hook into the IP layer itself

children.help:
Enabling this option performs a check (via ARP request) if the offered IP address
is not already in use by another host on the network.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DOES_ARP_CHECK
children.title: DHCP: Perform ARP check on any offered address

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers used by LwIP SNTP module.
First argument of sntp_setserver/sntp_setservername functions
is limited to this value.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_MAX_NTP_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers

children.help:
The DHCP server is calculating lease time multiplying the sent
and received times by this number of seconds per unit.
The default is 60, that equals one minute.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_LEASE_UNIT
children.title: Multiplier for lease time, in seconds

children.help:
The maximum number of DHCP clients that are connected to the server.
After this number is exceeded, DHCP server removes of the oldest device
from it's address pool, without notification.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_MAX_STATION_NUM
children.title: Maximum number of stations

children.help: Set time interval of retransmissions of DHCP discover.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DISCOVER_RETRANSMISSION_INTERVAL
children.title: DHCP discover retransmission interval (milliseconds)

children.help:
DHCP client will send this many probes before self-assigning a
link local address.

From LWIP help: "This can be set as low as 1 to get an AutoIP
address very quickly, but you should be prepared to handle a
changing IP address when DHCP overrides AutoIP."
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_AUTOIP_COOP_TRIES
children.title: DHCP Probes before self-assigning IPv4 LL address

children.help:
If the AUTOIP functionality detects this many IP conflicts while
self-assigning an address, it will go into a rate limited mode.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_MAX_CONFLICTS
children.title: Max IP conflicts before rate limiting

children.help:
If rate limiting self-assignment requests, wait this long between
each request.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Rate limited interval (seconds)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to self-assign an address
in the 169.256/16 range if none is assigned statically or via DHCP.

See RFC 3927.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP
children.title: Enable IPV4 Link-Local Addressing (AUTOIP)

children.help:
Enable this option, espressif advansed DNS functions will be enable. User can set the
reserved DNS server(its index is DNS_FALLBACK_SERVER_INDEX) which will not be changed by DHCP.
children.name: ESP_DNS
children.title: Enable espressif advansed DNS

children.help:
Configure the maximum number of packets which can be queued for
loopback on a given interface. Reducing this number may cause packets
to be dropped, but will avoid filling memory with queued packet data.
children.name: LWIP_LOOPBACK_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: Max queued loopback packets per interface

children.help:
Enabling this option means that if a packet is sent with a destination
address equal to the interface's own IP address, it will "loop back" and
be received by this interface.
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_LOOPBACK
children.title: Enable per-interface loopback

children.help: "Enable this option, TCP retransmissions time will always be set to 500ms forcely."
children.name: TCP_HIGH_SPEED_RETRANSMISSION
children.title: TCP high speed retransmissions

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_ACTIVE_TCP
children.title: Maximum active TCP Connections

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously listening TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new listening TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_LISTENING_TCP
children.title: Maximum listening TCP Connections

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of data segments.
children.name: TCP_MAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of data segments

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments.
children.name: TCP_SYNMAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments

children.help:
Set maximum segment size for TCP transmission.

Can be set lower to save RAM, the default value 1436 will give best throughput.
children.name: TCP_MSS
children.title: Maximum Segment Size (MSS)

children.help:
Set default send buffer size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket send buffer size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_SNDBUF, ...).

This value must be at least 2x the MSS size, and the default
is 4x the default MSS size.

Setting a smaller default SNDBUF size can save some RAM, but
will decrease performance.
children.name: TCP_SND_BUF_DEFAULT
children.title: Default send buffer size

children.help:
Set default TCP receive window size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket receive window size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_WINDOW, ...).

Setting a smaller default receive window size can save some RAM,
but will significantly decrease performance.
children.name: TCP_WND_DEFAULT
children.title: Default receive window size

children.help:
Set TCP receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The recommended value is: TCP_WND_DEFAULT/TCP_MSS + 2, e.g. if
TCP_WND_DEFAULT=14360, TCP_MSS=1436, then the recommended receive mail box size is
(14360/1436 + 2) = 12.

TCP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from TCP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to TCP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each TCP socket, so the maximum possible cached TCP packets
for all TCP sockets is TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum TCP socket number. In other
words, the bigger TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the TCP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default TCP receive mail box size

children.help:
Queue incoming out-of-order segments for later use.

Disable this option to save some RAM during TCP sessions, at the expense
of increased retransmissions if segments arrive out of order.
children.name: TCP_QUEUE_OOSEQ
children.title: Queue incoming out-of-order segments

children.help:
Allows enabling "oversize" allocation of TCP transmission pbufs ahead of time,
which can reduce the length of pbuf chains used for transmission.

This will not make a difference to sockets where Nagle's algorithm
is disabled.

Default value of MSS is fine for most applications, 25% MSS may save
some RAM when only transmitting small amounts of data. Disabled will
have worst performance and fragmentation characteristics, but uses
least RAM overall.
children.name: TCP_OVERSIZE
children.title: Pre-allocate transmit PBUF size

children.help:
The timestamp option is currently only used to help remote hosts, it is not
really used locally. Therefore, it is only enabled when a TS option is
received in the initial SYN packet from a remote host.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_TIMESTAMPS
children.title: Support the TCP timestamp option

children.help:
The maximum number of active UDP "connections" (ie
UDP sockets sending/receiving data).
The practical maximum limit is determined by available
heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_UDP_PCBS
children.title: Maximum active UDP control blocks

children.help:
Set UDP receive mail box size. The recommended value is 6.

UDP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from UDP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to UDP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each UDP socket, so the maximum possible cached UDP packets
for all UDP sockets is UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum UDP socket number. In other
words, the bigger UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the UDP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default UDP receive mail box size

children.help:
Configure TCP/IP task stack size, used by LWIP to process multi-threaded TCP/IP operations.
Setting this stack too small will result in stack overflow crashes.
children.name: TCPIP_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: TCP/IP Task Stack Size

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active LWIP
RAW protocol control blocks. The practical maximum
limit is determined by available heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_RAW_PCBS
children.title: Maximum LWIP RAW PCBs

children.name: LWIP_IPV6_NUM_ADDRESSES
children.title: Number of IPv6 addresses per netif

children.name: LWIP_IPV6_FRAG
children.title: Fragment outgoing IPv6 packets that are too big

children.help:
Use IPv6 Router Advertisement Recursive DNS Server Option (as per RFC 6106)
to copy a defined maximum number of DNS servers to the DNS module
children.name: LWIP_ND6_RDNSS_MAX_DNS_SERVERS
children.title: The IPv6 ND6 RDNSS max DNS servers

children.help:
Enable this option, LWIP allocated memory information can be traced by "heap" components.

User can call "heap_trace_start(HEAP_TRACE_LEAKS)" to start tracing and call "heap_trace_dump()"
to list the memory map.
children.name: ESP_LWIP_MEM_DBG
children.title: Enable LWIP memory debug

children.name: LWIP_IP_REASS_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in ip_frag.c for both frag & reass

children.name: LWIP_TCP_INPUT_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in tcp_in.c for incoming debug

children.name: LWIP_TCP_FR_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in tcp_in.c for fast retransmit

children.name: LWIP_TCP_RTO_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in TCP for retransmit

children.name: LWIP_TCP_CWND_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging for TCP congestion window

children.name: LWIP_TCP_WND_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in tcp_in.c for window updating

children.name: LWIP_TCP_OUTPUT_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging in tcp_out.c output functions

children.name: LWIP_TCP_RST_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging for TCP with the RST message

children.name: LWIP_TCP_QLEN_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging for TCP queue lengths

children.name: LWIP_THREAD_SAFE_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging for LWIP thread safety.

children.name: LWIP_PBUF_CACHE_DEBUG
children.title: Enable debugging for LWIP pbuf cache.

children.help: Define maximum number of partitions that can be mounted.
children.name: SPIFFS_MAX_PARTITIONS
children.title: Maximum Number of Partitions

children.help: Enables memory write caching for file descriptors in hydrogen.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_WR
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Write Caching

children.help: Enable/disable statistics on caching. Debug/test purpose only.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_STATS
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache Statistics

children.help:
Enables/disable memory read caching of nucleus file system
operations.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache

children.help:
Always check header of each accessed page to ensure consistent state.
If enabled it will increase number of reads from flash, especially
if cache is disabled.
children.name: SPIFFS_PAGE_CHECK
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Page Check

children.help: Define maximum number of GC runs to perform to reach desired free pages.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_MAX_RUNS
children.title: Set Maximum GC Runs

children.help: Enable/disable statistics on gc. Debug/test purpose only.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_STATS
children.title: Enable SPIFFS GC Statistics

children.help:
Logical page size of SPIFFS partition, in bytes. Must be multiple
of flash page size (which is usually 256 bytes).
Larger page sizes reduce overhead when storing large files, and
improve filesystem performance when reading large files.
Smaller page sizes reduce overhead when storing small (< page size)
files.
children.name: SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE
children.title: SPIFFS logical page size

children.help:
Object name maximum length. Note that this length include the
zero-termination character, meaning maximum string of characters
can at most be SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN - 1.

SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN + SPIFFS_META_LENGTH should not exceed
SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE - 64.
children.name: SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN
children.title: Set SPIFFS Maximum Name Length

children.help:
If this option is enabled, the magic will also be dependent
on the length of the filesystem. For example, a filesystem
configured and formatted for 4 megabytes will not be accepted
for mounting with a configuration defining the filesystem as 2 megabytes.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MAGIC_LENGTH
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Length Magic

children.help:
Enable this to have an identifiable spiffs filesystem.
This will look for a magic in all sectors to determine if this
is a valid spiffs system or not at mount time.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MAGIC
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Magic

children.help:
This option sets the number of extra bytes stored in the file header.
These bytes can be used in an application-specific manner.
Set this to at least 4 bytes to enable support for saving file
modification time.

SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN + SPIFFS_META_LENGTH should not exceed
SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE - 64.
children.name: SPIFFS_META_LENGTH
children.title: Size of per-file metadata field

children.help:
If enabled, then the first 4 bytes of per-file metadata will be used
to store file modification time (mtime), accessible through
stat/fstat functions.
Modification time is updated when the file is opened.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MTIME
children.title: Save file modification time

children.help: Enabling this option will print general debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_DBG
children.title: Enable general SPIFFS debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print API debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_API_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS API debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print GC debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Garbage Cleaner debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print cache debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache debug

children.help:
Enabling this option will print Filesystem Check debug mesages
to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_CHECK_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Check debug

children.help: Enable this option to enable SPIFFS_vis function in the API.
children.name: SPIFFS_TEST_VISUALISATION
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Visualization

children.help: Select this option to enable support for the SPIFFS.
children.name: USING_SPIFFS
children.title: SPIFFS

children.help: This sets the maximum supported size of headers section in HTTP request packet to be processed by the server
children.name: HTTPD_MAX_REQ_HDR_LEN
children.title: Max HTTP Request Header Length

children.help: This sets the maximum supported size of HTTP request URI to be processed by the server
children.name: HTTPD_MAX_URI_LEN
children.title: Max HTTP URI Length

children.help:
Select() related functions might produce an unconveniently lot of
debug outputs when one sets the default log level to DEBUG or higher.
It is possible to suppress these debug outputs by enabling this
option.
children.name: SUPPRESS_SELECT_DEBUG_OUTPUT
children.title: Suppress select() related debug outputs

children.help: Disabling this option can save memory when the support for termios.h is not required.
children.name: SUPPORT_TERMIOS
children.title: Add support for termios.h

children.help:
Enable this option, espressif  VFS can be used. Users can use APIs like "open", "read", "write"
and so on to operate I/O device which is registered.
children.name: USING_ESP_VFS
children.title: Using espressif VFS

children.name: SSL_USING_WOLFSSL
children.title: wolfSSL (License info in wolfssl subdirectory README)

children.help:
Choose the SSL/TLS library which you want to use.

Currently we support mbedTLS and axTLS.
children.name: SSL_LIBRARY_CHOOSE
children.title: Choose SSL/TLS library

children.help: Enable wolfSSL debugging functions at compile time.
children.name: WOLFSSL_DEBUG
children.title: Enable wolfSSL debugging

children.help:
Maximum TLS output message length (in bytes) supported by mbedTLS.

You can set a lower value than 16384 bytes in order to save RAM.
This is safe if the other end of the connection supports Maximum
Fragment Length Negotiation Extension (max_fragment_length,
see RFC6066) or you know for certain that it will never send a
message longer than a certain number of bytes.

If the value is set too low, symptoms are a failed TLS
handshake or a return value of MBEDTLS_ERR_SSL_INVALID_RECORD
(-0x7200).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_OUT_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum OUTPUT message content length

children.help:
Maximum TLS input message length (in bytes) supported by mbedTLS.

16384 is the default and this value is required to comply
fully with TLS standards.

However you can set a lower value in order to save RAM. This
is safe if the other end of the connection supports Maximum
Fragment Length Negotiation Extension (max_fragment_length,
see RFC6066) or you know for certain that it will never send a
message longer than a certain number of bytes.

If the value is set too low, symptoms are a failed TLS
handshake or a return value of MBEDTLS_ERR_SSL_INVALID_RECORD
(-0x7200).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_IN_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum INPUT message content length

children.help:
mbedTLS's minimum bit length is 2048, but some customers's key RSA bits is 1024.

With the option users can configurate the value to make mbedTLS support 1024 bits RSA key.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RSA_BITLEN_MIN
children.title: RSA minimum bit length

children.help: Mbedtls debugging level.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DEBUG_LEVEL
children.title: Mbedtls debugging level

children.help:
Enable mbedTLS debugging functions at compile time.

If this option is enabled, you must call mbedtls_esp_enable_debug_log
    at runtime in order to enable mbedTLS debug output.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DEBUG
children.title: Enable mbedTLS debugging

children.help:
System has time.h and time(), gmtime() and the clock is correct.
The time needs to be correct (not necesarily very accurate, but at least
the date should be correct). This is used to verify the validity period of
X.509 certificates.

It is suggested that you should get the real time by "SNTP".
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME_DATE
children.title: Enable mbedtls time data

children.help:
System has time.h and time().
The time does not need to be correct, only time differences are used,
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME
children.title: Enable mbedtls time

children.help:
mbedTLS can be compiled with protocol support for the TLS
server, TLS client, or both server and client.

Reducing the number of TLS roles supported saves code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_TLS_MODE
children.title: TLS Protocol Role

children.help: Enable to support symmetric key PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS key exchange modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_PSK
children.title: Enable PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_PSK
children.title: Enable DHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Elliptic-Curve-Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_PSK
children.title: Enable ECDHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support RSA PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA_PSK
children.title: Enable RSA-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show configuration for different types of pre-shared-key TLS authentatication methods.

Leaving this options disabled will save code size if they are not used.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PSK_MODES
children.title: Enable pre-shared-key ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA
children.title: Enable RSA-only based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-DHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_RSA
children.title: Enable DHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show Elliptic Curve based ciphersuite mode options.

Disabling all Elliptic Curve ciphersuites saves code size and
can give slightly faster TLS handshakes, provided the server supports
RSA-only ciphersuite modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ELLIPTIC_CURVE
children.title: Support Elliptic Curve based ciphersuites

children.help:
The two main uses of renegotiation are (1) refresh keys on long-lived
connections and (2) client authentication after the initial handshake.
If you don't need renegotiation, disabling it will save code size and
reduce the possibility of abuse/vulnerability.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_RENEGOTIATION
children.title: Support TLS renegotiation

children.help:
Support the legacy SSL 3.0 protocol. Most servers will speak a newer
TLS protocol these days.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_SSL3
children.title: Legacy SSL 3.0 support

children.help:
Requires TLS 1.1 to be enabled for DTLS 1.0
Requires TLS 1.2 to be enabled for DTLS 1.2
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_DTLS
children.title: Support DTLS protocol (all versions)

children.help: Disabling this option will save some code size if it is not needed.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_ALPN
children.title: Support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol Negotiation)

children.help: Enable Counter Block Cipher mode (CTR) for symmetric ciphers. Required for AES CTR
children.name: MBEDTLS_CIPHER_MODE_CTR
children.title: Support CTR mode

children.help:
Support RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.

Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Support RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Enables the DES block cipher to support 3DES-based TLS ciphersuites.

3DES is vulnerable to the Sweet32 attack and should only be enabled
if absolutely necessary.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DES_C
children.title: DES block cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
ARCFOUR (RC4) stream cipher can be disabled entirely, enabled but not
added to default ciphersuites, or enabled completely.

Please consider the security implications before enabling RC4.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RC4_MODE
children.title: RC4 Stream Cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
Enables the Blowfish block cipher (not used for TLS sessions.)

The Blowfish cipher is not used for mbedTLS TLS sessions but can be
used for other purposes. Read up on the limitations of Blowfish (including
Sweet32) before enabling.
children.name: MBEDTLS_BLOWFISH_C
children.title: Blowfish block cipher (read help)

children.help: Enables the XTEA block cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_XTEA_C
children.title: XTEA block cipher

children.help:
Enable Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM) modes for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CCM_C
children.title: CCM (Counter with CBC-MAC) block cipher modes

children.help:
Enable Galois/Counter Mode for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

This option is generally faster than CCM.
children.name: MBEDTLS_GCM_C
children.title: GCM (Galois/Counter) block cipher modes

children.help: Enable the RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RIPEMD160_C
children.title: Enable RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm

children.help:
Enable decoding/parsing of PEM formatted certificates.

If your certificates are all in the simpler DER format, disabling
this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_PARSE_C
children.title: Read & Parse PEM formatted certificates

children.help:
Enable writing of PEM formatted certificates.

If writing certificate data only in DER format, disabling this
option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_WRITE_C
children.title: Write PEM formatted certificates

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Revocation Lists.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CRL_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CRL parsing

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Signing Requests
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CSR_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CSR parsing

children.help: Enable ECDH. Needed to use ECDHE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDH_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)

children.help: Enable the Diffie-Hellman-Merkle module.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DHM_C
children.title: Diffie-Hellman-Merkle(DHM)

children.help: Enable ECDSA. Needed to use ECDSA-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve DSA

children.help: Enable support for SECP192R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP384R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP384R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP521R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP521R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP521R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP192K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256K1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP256R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP384R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP512R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP512R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for CURVE25519 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE25519_ENABLED
children.title: Enable CURVE25519 curve

children.help:
NIST 'modulo p' optimisations increase Elliptic Curve operation performance.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_NIST_OPTIM
children.title: NIST 'modulo p' optimisations

children.help:
OpenSSL debugging level.

Only function whose debugging level is higher than "OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL" works.

For example:
    If OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL = 2, you use function "SSL_DEBUG(1, "malloc failed")". Because 1 < 2, it will not print.
children.name: OPENSSL_DEBUG_LEVEL
children.title: OpenSSL debugging level

children.help: If the option is enabled, low-level module debugging function of OpenSSL is enabled, e.g. mbedtls internal debugging function.
children.name: OPENSSL_LOWLEVEL_DEBUG
children.title: Enable OpenSSL low-level module debugging

children.help:
Enable OpenSSL debugging function.

If the option is enabled, "SSL_DEBUG" works.
children.name: OPENSSL_DEBUG
children.title: Enable OpenSSL debugging

children.help: Do nothing and "SSL_ASSERT" does not work.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DO_NOTHING
children.title: Do nothing

children.help: Enable assert exiting, it will check and return error code.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_EXIT
children.title: Check and exit

children.help: Enable assert debugging, it will check and show debugging message.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG
children.title: Show debugging message

children.help: Enable assert debugging and exiting, it will check, show debugging message and return error code.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG_EXIT
children.title: Show debugging message and exit

children.help: Enable assert debugging and blocking, it will check, show debugging message and block by "while (1);".
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT_DEBUG_BLOCK
children.title: Show debugging message and block

children.help:
OpenSSL function needs "assert" function to check if input parameters are valid.

If you want to use assert debugging function, "OPENSSL_DEBUG" should be enabled.
children.name: OPENSSL_ASSERT
children.title: Select OpenSSL assert function

children.help: This option will enable https protocol by linking mbedtls library and initializing SSL transport
children.name: ESP_HTTP_CLIENT_ENABLE_HTTPS
children.title: Enable https

children.help:
The value of 0 indicates the IP lost timer is disabled, otherwise the timer is enabled.

The IP address may be lost because of some reasons, e.g. when the station disconnects
from soft-AP, or when DHCP IP renew fails etc. If the IP lost timer is enabled, it will
be started everytime the IP is lost. Event SYSTEM_EVENT_STA_LOST_IP will be raised if
the timer expires. The IP lost timer is stopped if the station get the IP again before
the timer expires.
children.name: IP_LOST_TIMER_INTERVAL
children.title: IP Address lost timer interval (seconds)

children.help: Link TCPIP adapter global data(.bss .data COMMON) from DRAM to IRAM.
children.name: TCPIP_ADAPTER_GLOBAL_DATA_LINK_IRAM
children.title: Link TCPIP adapter global data to IRAM

children.help: If enable this option, app update will check the sum of app binary data after downloading it.
children.name: APP_UPDATE_CHECK_APP_SUM
children.title: Check APP binary data sum after downloading

children.help: If enable this option, app update will check the hash of app binary data after downloading it.
children.name: APP_UPDATE_CHECK_APP_HASH
children.title: Check APP binary data hash after downloading

children.help: Enable this option, espressif console can be used.
children.name: USING_ESP_CONSOLE
children.title: Using Espressif Console

children.help: CPU frequency to be set on application startup.
children.name: ESP8266_DEFAULT_CPU_FREQ_MHZ
children.title: CPU frequency

children.help:
This option allows configuring the desired line endings sent to UART
when a newline ('\n', LF) appears on stdout.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: whenever LF is encountered, prepend it with CR

LF: no modification is applied, stdout is sent as is

CR: each occurence of LF is replaced with CR

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDOUT_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART output

children.help:
This option allows configuring the macro __ESP_FILE__ text.
Three options are possible:

no PATH: strip the path of macro __FILE__, for example: __FILE__="a/b/c/d.h", then __ESP_FILE__="d.h"

raw: same as macro __FILE__

null: text is string "null"
children.name: ESP_FILENAME_MACRO
children.title: File name macro text

children.help:
Enable this option, SDK will use new "ets_vprintf" function instead of old code "ets_vprintf" which is depend on ROM
code "ets_io_vprintf".

Note: Bootloader can't use this function.
children.name: USING_NEW_ETS_VPRINTF
children.title: Using new ets_vprintf instead of rom code

children.help:
Enable this option, SDK will link the old/new "ets_printf" and "ets_vprintf" to IRAM instead of flash.
So although flash can't be access for SoC when reading to writing, the "ets_printf" and "ets_vprintf" also can be used by user.

Using new "ets_vprintf" should cost more 1.6KB IRAM.

Note: Bootloader can't use this function.
children.name: LINK_ETS_PRINTF_TO_IRAM
children.title: Link ets_printf to IRAM

children.help:
Enable this option, full 32 KB iram instead of 16 KB iram will be used as icache, so the heap use can use
may reduce a lot.
children.name: SOC_FULL_ICACHE
children.title: Enable full cache mode

children.help:
Select whether to use UART for console output (through stdout and stderr).

- Default is to use UART0.
- If "Custom" is selected, UART0 or UART1 can be chosen.
- If "None" is selected, there will be no console output on any UART.
children.name: CONSOLE_UART
children.title: UART for console output

children.help: Configrate output console UART for "ets_printf", "printf", "ESP_LOGX" and so on.
children.name: CONSOLE_UART_NUM
children.title: UART peripheral to use for console output (0-1)

children.help: Enable this option, UART0's I/O pins are swaped: TXD <-> RTS, RTX <-> CTS.
children.name: UART0_SWAP_IO
children.title: Swap UART0 I/O pins

children.help: "Disable main part of ROM UART print when rom bootloader process."
children.name: DISABLE_ROM_UART_PRINT
children.title: Disable ROM UART print

children.help: Output full stack data of task although some stack space is not used.
children.name: PANIC_FULL_STACK
children.title: Output full stack data of task

children.help:
Outputs the relevant registers over the serial port and halt the
processor. Needs a manual reset to restart.
children.name: ESP_PANIC_PRINT_HALT
children.title: Print registers and halt

children.help:
Outputs the relevant registers over the serial port and immediately
reset the processor.
children.name: ESP_PANIC_PRINT_REBOOT
children.title: Print registers and reboot

children.help: Just resets the processor without outputting anything
children.name: ESP_PANIC_SILENT_REBOOT
children.title: Silent reboot

children.help:
If an unhandled exception, the panic handler is invoked.
Configure the panic handlers action here.
children.name: ESP_PANIC
children.title: Panic handler behaviour

children.help:
Configure the "main task" stack size. This is the stack of the task
which calls app_main(). If app_main() returns then this task is deleted
and its stack memory is freed.
children.name: MAIN_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: Main task stack size

children.help:
The Task Watchdog Timer can be used to make sure individual tasks are still
running. Enabling this option will cause the Task Watchdog Timer to be
initialized automatically at startup. The Task Watchdog timer can be
initialized after startup as well.
children.name: TASK_WDT
children.title: Initialize Task Watchdog Timer on startup

children.help:
If this option is enabled, the Task Watchdog Timer will be configured to
trigger the panic handler when it times out. And it may cost some time.
children.name: TASK_WDT_PANIC
children.title: Invoke panic handler on Task Watchdog timeout

children.help:
Timeout period configuration for the Task Watchdog Timer in seconds.
This is also configurable at run time.
children.name: TASK_WDT_TIMEOUT_S
children.title: Task Watchdog timeout period (seconds)

children.help: Enable this option, the reset reason function can be used, or compiler will show function linking error.
children.name: RESET_REASON
children.title: Enable reset reason

children.help:
Configure the "ppT task" stack size. This is the stack of the task
which calls promiscuous callback function. So if user's function is
complex, the stack must be set larger.
children.name: WIFI_PPT_TASKSTACK_SIZE
children.title: ppT task stack size

children.help: Configure the Event loop task stack size per application.
children.name: EVENT_LOOP_STACK_SIZE
children.title: Event loop stack size

children.help: Link libcore.a internal global data(.bss .data COMMON) from DRAM to IRAM.
children.name: ESP8266_CORE_GLOBAL_DATA_LINK_IRAM
children.title: Link libcore.a internal global data to IRAM

children.help:
For most modules, 26MHz is the default crystal. If you use special module,
you can reconfigure this option.
children.name: CRYSTAL_USED
children.title: Crystal used in your module or board

children.help:
Some OSes should initialize their global data structure before starting them. rt-thread is like this one.

FreeRTOS need not do this.
children.name: INIT_OS_BEFORE_START
children.title: Init OS before starting it

children.help:
The function is not released.

Enable this option, after updating from old SDK to new SDK, bootloader will copy RF
parameters from old SDK partition to new SDK partition.

Then application can read the RF parameters from new partition directly.
children.name: LOAD_OLD_RF_PARAMETER
children.title: Load old RF Parameters

children.help:
The function is not released.

Enable this option, script will generate the complete firmware for both old RTOS SDK(before V3.0)
and NonOS SDK to update to v3 by OTA.

The old RTOS SDK(before V3.0) or NonOS SDK can download the firmware to its partition and run it as it self's application.
children.name: ESP8266_OTA_FROM_OLD
children.title: ESP8266 update from old SDK by OTA

children.help:
The function is not released.

Enable this option, when it is that "OTA1" application is to run after update by OTA,
bootloader will copy "OTA1" application to "OTA0" partition and run "OTA0".
children.name: ESP8266_BOOT_COPY_APP
children.title: Boot copy app

children.help:
Functions esp_err_to_name() and esp_err_to_name_r() return string
representations of error codes from a pre-generated lookup table.
This option can be used to turn off the use of the look-up table in
order to save memory but this comes at the price of sacrificing
distinguishable (meaningful) output string representations.
children.name: ESP_ERR_TO_NAME_LOOKUP
children.title: Enable lookup of error code strings

children.help:
Function "esp_wifi_scan_get_ap_num" return value will be less than this. It is said that user cannot
scan more than this.

User can use own function "esp_wifi_scan_get_ap_num_max" to determin how many AP to scan , too.
children.name: SCAN_AP_MAX
children.title: Max scan AP number

children.help:
If this option is enabled, Wifi will try to send packets first from high rate(54M). If it fails, it will
try at low rate until the transmission is successful.
children.name: WIFI_TX_RATE_SEQUENCE_FROM_HIGH
children.title: Set wifi tx rate from 54M to 1M

children.help:
The WiFi log is divided into the following levels: ERROR,WARNING,INFO,DEBUG,VERBOSE.
The ERROR level is enabled by default, and the WARNING,INFO,DEBUG,VERBOSE levels can be enabled here.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_LEVEL
children.title: The DEBUG level is enabled

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for core module will be enabled..
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_CORE
children.title: core

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for scan module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_SCAN
children.title: scan

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for power management module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_PM
children.title: power management

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for NVS module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_NVS
children.title: NVS

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for TRC module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_TRC
children.title: TRC

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for EBUF module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_EBUF
children.title: EBUF

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for net80211 module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_NET80211
children.title: NET80211

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for timer module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_TIMER
children.title: TIMER

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for espnow module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_ESPNOW
children.title: ESPNOW

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for mac layer module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_MAC
children.title: MAC layer

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for wpa module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_WPA
children.title: wpa

children.help: When this option is enabled, log for wps module will be enabled.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE_WPS
children.title: wps

children.help:
Enable this option to set the WiFi debug log submodule.
Currently the log submodule contains the following parts: INIT,IOCTL,CONN,SCAN.
The INIT submodule indicates the initialization process.The IOCTL submodule indicates the API calling
process.
The CONN submodule indicates the connecting process.The SCAN submodule indicates the scaning process.
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_SUBMODULE
children.title: WiFi debug log submodule

children.help: Select this option to enable WiFi debug log
children.name: ESP8266_WIFI_DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE
children.title: Enable WiFi debug log

children.help:
If this option is enabled, NVS will be initialized and calibration data will be loaded from there.
PHY calibration will be skipped on deep sleep wakeup. If calibration data is not found, full calibration
will be performed and stored in NVS. Normally, only partial calibration will be performed.
If this option is disabled, full calibration will be performed.

If it's easy that your board calibrate bad data, choose 'n'.
Two cases for example, you should choose 'n':
1.If your board is easy to be booted up with antenna disconnected.
2.Because of your board design, each time when you do calibration, the result are too unstable.
If unsure, choose 'y'.
children.name: ESP_PHY_CALIBRATION_AND_DATA_STORAGE
children.title: Store phy calibration data in NVS

children.help:
If enabled, PHY init data will be loaded from a partition.
When using a custom partition table, make sure that PHY data
partition is included (type: 'data', subtype: 'phy').
With default partition tables, this is done automatically.
If PHY init data is stored in a partition, it has to be flashed there,
otherwise runtime error will occur.

If this option is not enabled, PHY init data will be embedded
into the application binary.

If unsure, choose 'n'.
children.name: ESP_PHY_INIT_DATA_IN_PARTITION
children.title: Use a partition to store PHY init data

children.help:
vdd33_const provides ADC mode settings, i.e. selecting system voltage or external voltage measurements.
When measuring system voltage, it must be set to 255.
To read the external voltage on TOUT(ADC) pin, vdd33_const need less than 255
When the ADC reference voltage is set to the actual VDD33 power supply voltage, the value range of vdd33_const is [18,36], the unit is 0.1V.
When the ADC reference voltage is set to the default value of 3.3V as the supply voltage, the range of vdd33_const is [0, 18] or (36, 255).
children.name: ESP_PHY_INIT_DATA_VDD33_CONST
children.title: vdd33_const value

children.help:
Set maximum transmit power for WiFi radio. Actual transmit power for high
data rates may be lower than this setting.
children.name: ESP8266_PHY_MAX_WIFI_TX_POWER
children.title: Max WiFi TX power (dBm)

children.help:
Enable this option, util components will use assert to check if input
parameters are correct.

Disable this option will speed up the process of some calculation a lot.
children.name: util_assert
children.title: Enable assert for util components

children.help:
Enable Espressif SHA1, SHA256, SHA384 & SHA512 for other components to
save code size for ESP8285(ESP8266 + 1MB flash) users.

Although this option is disable, bootloader will use it if booloader
is configured to use SHA256 to check hash.

Disabling the "assert" function at menuconfig can speed up the calculation.
children.name: ESP_SHA
children.title: Enable Espressif SHA

children.help:
Enable Espressif AES ECB, CBC, CFB128, CFB8 & CRT for other components to
speed up process speed and save code size.

ESP8285 is like ESP8266 + 1MB flash, but its internal I/O connection from CPU
core to flash is DIO not QIO, which makes it read flash data slower.
So the function will speed up ESP8285 obviously.

The calculation uses "ibus_data" to speed up load data from instruction bus.

Disabling the "assert" function at menuconfig can speed up the calculation.
children.name: ESP_AES
children.title: Enable Espressif AES

children.help:
Enable Espressif MD5 for other components to
speed up process speed and save code size.

ESP8285 is like ESP8266 + 1MB flash, but its internal I/O connection from CPU
core to flash is DIO not QIO, which makes it read flash data slower.
So the function will speed up ESP8285 obviously.

The calculation uses "ibus_data" to speed up load data from instruction bus.

Disabling the "assert" function at menuconfig can speed up the calculation.
children.name: ESP_MD5
children.title: Enable Espressif MD5

children.help:
Enable Espressif ARC4 for other components to
speed up process speed and save code size.

ESP8285 is like ESP8266 + 1MB flash, but its internal I/O connection from CPU
core to flash is DIO not QIO, which makes it read flash data slower.
So the function will speed up ESP8285 obviously.

The calculation uses "ibus_data" to speed up load data from instruction bus.

Disabling the "assert" function at menuconfig can speed up the calculation.
children.name: ESP_ARC4
children.title: Enable Espressif ARC4

children.help: Enable this option and then pthread is to be used.
children.name: ENABLE_PTHREAD
children.title: Enable pthread

children.help: Priority used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: ESP32_PTHREAD_TASK_PRIO_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task priority

children.help: Stack size used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: ESP32_PTHREAD_TASK_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task stack size

children.help:
Enable this option, FreeRTOS will not be compiled and linked, and the user
can user other OS platform.
children.name: DISABLE_FREERTOS
children.title: Disable FreeRTOS

children.help:
Enable "reent" function and FreeRTOS should use "reent" function of newlib.

The configuration will enable newlib.
children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_REENT
children.title: Enable "reent" function

children.help:
Select the tick rate at which FreeRTOS does pre-emptive context switching.

The value must be the divisor of 1000, otherwise it may cause time mistake.
children.name: FREERTOS_HZ
children.title: Tick rate (Hz)

children.help: configurate the max number of FreeRTOS hook function.
children.name: FREERTOS_MAX_HOOK
children.title: FreeRTOS hook max number

children.help:
The idle task has its own stack, sized in bytes. The default size is enough for most uses. Size can be reduced
to 1024 bytes if no (or simple) FreeRTOS idle hooks are used and pthread local storage or FreeRTOS local storage
cleanup callbacks are not used.

The stack size may need to be increased above the default if the app installs idle or thread local storage
cleanup hooks that use a lot of stack memory.
children.name: FREERTOS_IDLE_TASK_STACKSIZE
children.title: Idle Task stack size

children.help: The interrupt handlers have their own stack. The size of the stack can be defined here.
children.name: FREERTOS_ISR_STACKSIZE
children.title: ISR stack size

children.help:
By using the "esp_register_freertos_xxx_hook system", extened hook function offers a number
of registerable hooks/callback functions that are called when a timer tick happens,
the idle thread runs etc.

Otherwise User can also use FreeRTOS raw hook functions "vApplicationIdleHook" and
"vApplicationTickHook".
children.name: FREERTOS_EXTENED_HOOKS
children.title: Use FreeRTOS extened hooks

children.help: Link FreeRTOS global data(.bss .data COMMON) from DRAM to IRAM.
children.name: FREERTOS_GLOBAL_DATA_LINK_IRAM
children.title: Link FreeRTOS global data to IRAM

children.help: The size of the stack used by the timer in FreeRTOS.
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_STACKSIZE
children.title: Timer stack size

children.help:
Enable this option, linking task switch function and its father functions to IRAM
to speed up task switch. It is specific for faster I/O application and so on.

But it may cost more 1KB IRAM, so user global heap may decrease 1KB.
children.name: TASK_SWITCH_FASTER
children.title: Task switch faster

children.help: Enable this option, the FreeRTOS macro "configUSE_QUEUE_SETS" in file "FreeRTOSConfig.h" will be set to be 1.
children.name: USE_QUEUE_SETS
children.title: Using Queue Sets

children.help:
Enable this option, FreeRTOS sleep module at idle task will be enable.

The module is not working now, so if users want to make it work, they should do this themselves.
children.name: ENABLE_FREERTOS_SLEEP
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS SLEEP

children.help:
If enabled, configUSE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS will be defined as 1 in
FreeRTOS. This will allow the usage of stats formatting functions such
as vTaskList().
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS stats formatting functions

children.help:
If enabled, configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY will be defined as 1 in FreeRTOS.
This will allow the usage of trace facility functions such as
uxTaskGetSystemState().
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TRACE_FACILITY
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS trace facility

children.help:
ESP Timer will be used as the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats.
The ESP Timer runs at a frequency of 1MHz regardless of Dynamic
Frequency Scaling. Therefore the ESP Timer will overflow in
approximately 4290 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_ESP_TIMER
children.title: Use ESP TIMER for run time stats

children.help:
CPU Clock will be used as the clock source for the generation of run
time stats. The CPU Clock has a frequency dependent on
ESP32_DEFAULT_CPU_FREQ_MHZ and Dynamic Frequency Scaling (DFS).
Therefore the CPU Clock frequency can fluctuate between 80 to 240MHz.
Run time stats generated using the CPU Clock represents the number of
CPU cycles each task is allocated and DOES NOT reflect the amount of
time each task runs for (as CPU clock frequency can change). If the CPU
clock consistently runs at the maximum frequency of 240MHz, it will
overflow in approximately 17 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_CPU_CLK
children.title: Use CPU Clock for run time stats

children.help:
Choose the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats. Options are CPU0's
CPU Clock or the ESP Timer. Both clock sources are 32 bits. The CPU
Clock can run at a higher frequency hence provide a finer resolution
but will overflow much quicker. Note that run time stats are only valid
until the clock source overflows.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_CLK
children.title: Choose the clock source for run time stats

children.help:
If enabled, configGENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS will be defined as 1 in
FreeRTOS. This will allow FreeRTOS to collect information regarding the
usage of processor time amongst FreeRTOS tasks. Run time stats are
generated using either the ESP Timer or the CPU Clock as the clock
source (Note that run time stats are only valid until the clock source
overflows). The function vTaskGetRunTimeStats() will also be available
if FREERTOS_USE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS and
FREERTOS_USE_TRACE_FACILITY are enabled. vTaskGetRunTimeStats() will
display the run time of each task as a % of the total run time of all
CPUs (task run time / no of CPUs) / (total run time / 100 )
children.name: FREERTOS_GENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS to collect run time stats

children.help:
If this option is enabled, libsodium will use thin wrappers
around mbedTLS for SHA256 & SHA512 operations.

This saves some code size if mbedTLS is also used. However it
is incompatible with Espressif SHA (due to the
way libsodium's API manages SHA state).
children.name: LIBSODIUM_USE_MBEDTLS_SHA
children.title: Use mbedTLS SHA256 & SHA512 implementations

children.name: MQTT_USING_IBM
children.title: IBM-MQTT(not recommended and will be removed at v4.0)

children.help:
Choose the MQTT library which you want to use.

Currently we support ESP-MQTT and IBM-MQTT(paho).
children.name: MQTT_LIBRARY_CHOOSE
children.title: Choose MQTT library

children.help: Current supported MQTT version.
children.name: MQTT_VERSION
children.title: MQTT version

children.help: MQTT client ID for MQTT broker to identify ESP device.
children.name: MQTT_CLIENT_ID
children.title: MQTT client ID

children.help:
MQTT keep alive interval, Recommended value: 30s - 60s.
The last MQTT packet timestamp will be recorded,
a PING request will be sent if (current_timestamp - last_mqtt_packet_timestamp) > MQTT_KEEP_ALIVE.
children.name: MQTT_KEEP_ALIVE
children.title: MQTT keep-alive(seconds)

children.help:
Username used for logging to MQTT broker.
Generally, you should use a valid MQTT_USERNAME if MQTT broker does not allow an anonymous login.
children.name: MQTT_USERNAME
children.title: MQTT username

children.help:
Password used for logging to MQTT broker.
Generally, you should use a valid MQTT_PASSWORD if MQTT broker does not allow an anonymous login.
children.name: MQTT_PASSWORD
children.title: MQTT password

children.help:
Clean session to start a new session.
If clean-seesion is set, it will discard any previous session and start a new one.
If keep-session is set, it will store session state and the communication can resume.
children.name: MQTT_SESSION
children.title: MQTT Session

children.help:
MQTT over TCP/SSL/TLS.
MQTT_SECURITY=0: MQTT over TCP
MQTT_SECURITY=1: MQTT over TLS with no verify
MQTT_SECURITY=2: MQTT over TLS with verify peer
MQTT_SECURITY=3: MQTT over TLS with verify client
children.name: MQTT_SECURITY
children.title: MQTT over TCP/SSL/TLS feature

children.help:
Recommended value: 1460 - 2048.
